CatDescriptText: John W. Ford, Methodist minister, Brookline and Raymond Bluhm, student, Sheraden, was part of the "Pittsburghers Speak Up" column published in the Pittsburgh Courier Newspaper, January 28, 1961, pg. 21 with question: "Do you favor legislation or voluntary (appealing to the souls and conscience of men) methods, like arbitration, mediation, persuasion, etc., to obtain civil rights for minorities?" John W. Ford's answer reads: "It depends on the areas.  In housing, jobs and education, I favor legislation, because the other method is too slow.  There should be laws, but not without education.  Educational persuasion alone is too slow.  And you can't take time to persuade the other fellow that this is right.  If something is right, we should have laws for the sake of the fellow who cannot comply.  I think this is the same in all laws of moral..."  Ryamond Bluhm's answer reads: "I think there should be laws making the state help the people, and making it better for integration.  Conscience enters into the matter because it's a matter of conscience to make the laws."
